Employment: Employment status is based on the IPUMS variable ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÅempstatÃÂ¢Ãâ¬ÃÂ. This variable is not available in 1920. The reference period varies slightly across Censuses. In 1930 an individual is counted as employed if they were working on the most recent regular working day. In 1940 and later, an individual was counted as employed if they worked at all during the reference week. Prime-age employment is used as an outcome measure due to concerns about how the labor force and unemployment are measured across years. Prime-age workers are defined as individuals ages 25-54. Prime-age male employment is defined as the share of men in this age range who are employed.

Following Acemoglu et al. (2004), key defense industries are defined as durable goods manufacturing industries and these correspond to IPUMS 1950 industry codes 326-388. An additional issue is how to deal with top-coded values or implausibly low earnings totals. We follow Goldin and Katz (1992) by multiplying top-coded values by 1.4 and recoding as missing values that are less than 1/2 the minimum weekly wage. This corresponds to weekly earnings below $6 in 1940, $8 in 1950, $20 in 1960 and $28 in 1970.
Census aggregates. Census aggregates are taken from published Census volumes. County population totals by age and race are taking from ICPSR 02896 (Haines and ICPSR, 2010).

The secondary source of data are Selective Service System (1956). We digitized tables reporting total inductions and enlistments by service branch, month, and race. This data identifies how many inductions are not captured in the individual enlistment data for each month. We re-weight the individual observations by the number of records missing in their enlistment month. For example, if the individual records cover half of total inductions in a given month then the observed inductions will be given double the weight.
